unnormalised: Geometry, yaar! It's not just some boring subject we all suffered through in school. Turns out, understanding shapes and angles is super useful in, like, a million different ways. Think about it – architects designing buildings, engineers building bridges, even artists creating cool stuff – they all use geometry, right? And trig? Well, that's just geometry's slightly more complicated cousin, dealing with triangles and sine, cosine, and all that jazz. But don't worry, it’s not as scary as your 10th grade maths teacher made it seem!

But don't worry, it is not as scary as your tenth grade maths teacher made it seem!

unnormalised: Remember those Pythagoras theorem days? A squared plus B squared equals C squared? Still comes in handy if you're trying to figure out the dimensions of, say, your new TV. And all those formulas for area and volume? Yeah, maybe you won't use them every day, but trust me, they pop up in unexpected places. Like when you're trying to figure out how much paint you need to cover a 12x15 ft wall, or how much water your circular swimming pool (with a radius of 7 ft) holds.

unnormalised: Trigonometry can be a bit mind-bending, I agree. SOH CAH TOA was permanently stuck in my head. The good thing is, with modern technology, you don't need to remember all the exact values of sin 30° or cos 60° – calculators and online tools can handle that. But understanding the basic concepts is still important. Think about how surveyors use trig to map out land, or how GPS uses it to pinpoint your location on earth with surprising accuracy.

But understanding the basic concepts is still important. Think about how surveyors use trig to map out land, or how G-P-S uses it to pinpoint your location on earth with surprising accuracy.

unnormalised: And it's not just about practical applications. Geometry and trigonometry are also about developing problem-solving skills. They teach you how to think logically, break down complex problems into smaller, manageable parts, and find creative solutions. Skills that can come useful not just in mathematics, but practically everywhere, even when you're dealing with the daily office drama!

unnormalised: So, next time you're wondering why you had to learn about obtuse angles and right triangles, remember that it's not just about memorizing formulas. It's about developing a way of thinking, a way of seeing the world that can help you solve problems, create amazing things, and understand the world around you a little bit better. Plus, it impresses your friends when you casually mention something about angles of elevation, especially when you're overlooking that amazing view from a rooftop restaurant. The waiter might actually think you are an engineer!
